headline: Honey Wheat Bread II
description: This is a simple loaf with less whole wheat than many, but it still offers all the essential ingredients for a wholesome eating.
name: Honey Wheat Bread II
recipeIngredient: 2 cups warm water (110 degrees F/45 degrees C)

recipeInstructions.text: Dissolve yeast in warm water. Add honey, and stir well. Mix in whole wheat flour, salt, and vegetable oil. Work all-purpose flour in gradually. Turn dough out onto a lightly floured surface, and knead for at least 10 to 15 minutes. When dough is smooth and elastic, place it in a well oiled bowl. Turn it several times in the bowl to coat the surface of the dough, and cover with a damp cloth. Let rise in a warm place until doubled in bulk, about 45 minutes.
Punch down the dough. Shape into two loaves, and place into two well greased 9 x 5 inch loaf pans. Allow to rise until dough is 1 to 1 1/2 inches above pans.
Bake at 375 degrees F (190 degrees C) for 25 to 30 minutes.

review.reviewBody: Definitely needs more water and more salt but overall not too bad. Would make again with modifications.
Perfect! Best wheat bread I've made yet.
So yummy!! ❤️❤️❤️
Added some flax meal…. Baking now, rose well but a little slower due to more heavy grains… smells wonderful!

DELICIOUS WITH ALTERATIONS! used an 1/2 of wheat flour in place of the white flour and omitted 1/2 cup of white flour and it was still very dry dough so had to add couple tsp of water. I changed amounts of honey to 1/2 cup, added an extra 1/2 tsp of salt. I also added a packet of maple oatmeal and another 1/2 cup of oatmeal. It's very moist and next time, I think I'll add a bit more honey since I like my bread on the sweet side.
We enjoyed it!

I like the simplicity of this recipe. Albeit, my KA was not happy and had to stop and take over hand kneading. LOL. I need the exercise. Rose perfectly, cooked perfectly. Taste is much like you'd expect from wheat bread. This is a repeat after I find some nice loaf pans.
This is the best honey whole wheat bread. Super moist and never dry. Yas that’s what I need in a bread. You know what I mean you do know what I mean, right?

Great, simple recipe. I did flip the flour amounts (5 cups whole wheat & 2 cup white bread flour) plus increased the honey to 1/2 cup and added two eggs. By far the best wheat bread I’ve made. I also added a tablespoon of wheat gluten for each cup of the whole wheat flour. Really great loaf size, and great taste. I can’t wait to make it again.
Super easy and delicious
I found this to be a little dry. The overall flavor was good though.

This was so easy and it made the best tasting bread! Nice crumb, too!

Like others, I swapped an additional cup of whole wheat flour for white flour. I also increased honey to 1/2 cup. 

The whole wheat takes longer to rise. I had to place it in a small room with a space heater to get it to rise faster. That worked perfectly!

For my first try I decided to make this recipe exactly as written. It was very dense, not like soft sandwich bread at all. I suspect because the flour/liquid ratio is not right. The flavor was ok so we are using it to make toast! I decided to make another batch (with adjustments) and it was 100% better! I reduced the flour to a total of 5 cups (3 c wheat, 2 cups bread flour), replaced the oil with 5 tbs of melted butter, doubled the honey to 2/3 c, increased the water to 2 1/3 cups and reduced the Active Yeast to 2 tsp. 
I believe this is a near perfect loaf of bread! It's so soft and delicious. Now we will see how it freezes!
This recipe is easy and delicious. I will make again
Turned out yummy!! Easy and I’ll be making this one again!
Very good recipe, I'll be making this regularly. This would also make outstanding whole wheat rolls if you were so inclined
Very accurate recipe. Great taste.
Tastes amazing ,great consistency , simple to follow
Great for sandwiches. Was very happy with this recipe
I've made this twice now...and though the taste was good, the bread was REALLY dense and did not rise.
So yummy and very delicious!!
I first made this bread 5 years ago. Keeping the recipe as it is, it turns out every time. I find it heartier than store bought — after all, isn’t that why homemade bread is so good?

I have made bread before, which had turned out beautifully and made lovely loaves. But I was not quite satisfied with the taste so I thought I’d try a different but similar recipe. 
Being a novice bread maker it did not occur to me to check the measurements on this recipe so I simple started throwing ingredients together. Which is when I realized something was terribly wrong. I checked the recipe and my measurements and all was spot on. But there is waaayyyy too much flour for this recipe. I do not know how people were able to add the full 5 cups of flour unless they didn’t and just went by feel instead. Which isn’t very good help for novices like myself. 
So wish me luck that I can somehow make this dough into some reasonable bread.

Finally, a simple wheat recipe that doesn't require so many additional steps! I did want something a little healthier so per one of the reviews I did use 5 cups of whole wheat, plus a cup or 2 of all purpose just until it wasn't sticking to the sides of the bowl. And per alot of the reviews I did up the honey to 2/3 cup and also upped the salt to 1 1/2 tsp. It only took 30 min at 375 in my oven and it was definitely done. I do wish the directions explained to use UP to 5 cups of white flour - do not pour it in all at once, and then u won't need to add more water like one of the reviews said. Start with the 5 cups wheat and about 1 cup white, mix for 2 min, and then add about 1/2 cup of flour until dough is pulling away clean from sides of bowl (mixing for about 8-10 min total), and then whatever is needed to shape into dough ball. That being said, I was looking for a recipe that allowed me to use more wheat than white flour and this is def it! Thank you!
Ok at best, even doubled the salt and honey like reviews suggested.. not something I will be making again

Please, PLEASE update the original recipe to include the proper amount of water!!!! I should have read the worst reviews first and added more than a few extra tablespoons of water. Now my very expensive KitchenAid mixer is smoking and I think it's broken and the bread didn't turn out well after all. I'm so mad/sad/disappointed!

I've tried a lot of bread recipes and this is by far the best. Small tip, I did measure out two cups of the whole wheat flour but for the all purpose flour I went by weight. I used 22 ounces instead of 5 cups and used a kitchen scale. Also, based on other reviews I did add extra honey. I used 1/2 cup. With those tweaks it was perfect.
Needs double salt
Does need NEARLY as much flour as the recipe says! I only used about half the amount of AP flour.
Easy and delicious!
I use a cup of almond flour and coconut oil for amendments after making the recipe about 20 times. Original or with the tweaks, it's an awesome recipe!
first time making bread from scratch. I thought it would be as easy as muffins.. lol... but my bread came out heavy :-( not sure what i did.... maybe over mixed it?
Doubled the honey. Very good bread. Will make again.

Love this recipe, I can change it and do basically anything I want with it! I added oats and made a honey oat bread, then cinnamon and raisins, and the original is pretty good as Well! I used white bread flour to make this

After reading the reviews, I increased the honey to 1/2 c, 1 tbsp (3 tsp) yeast and 1 & 1/2 tsp salt
I used 2 c of bread flour (because I forgot) and 3 c of all purpose flour. 
This was an easy to follow and easy to make recipe. It smelled AMAZING while baking and turned out INCREDIBLE. I WILL be making it again. I will make it at the recommended 1/3 c honey. 1/2 c was a bit sweeter than I wanted for an everyday bread but it still tasted great when I made a hot ham and swiss!! 
Thanks for the great share!!! This will definitely be a staple in my home!! ??

This is an absolutely delicious recipe! My family gobbled the bread in a day or two and we couldn't even wait until it was cooled, hah! The only downside: the time it takes for the dough to rise. It's my fault for being so impatient, but it's definitely worth it in the end.
Simple recipe and everyone who tried the bread loved it! Like other reviewers, I increased the honey amount to half a cup. The bread tasted great and toasted very well for making BLT's.

The only complaint I have for this recipe is that the proportions are pretty far off. This has seven cups of the flours and olny 2 and 2 thirds cups of liquids. Way too dry. I suggest adjusting the liquids and adding flours slowly while mixing. Once you get that figured out it's a great bread.
An excellent bread. I highly recommend. Didn’t change a thing. Thank you for a keeper.
This is easy and tasty. I have made it my main whole wheat bread recipe.
I began making this bread in September 2014 and my family absolutely LOVES it. I often bake it and give it to family members during fall/winter months. Love it!!!
Good stuff. I used raw dark honey at the prescribed measurement and it was fantastic! I only used that because I had less store-bought honey than I thought and asked the neighbors if they had any. :P
Super reliable and easy recipe. I've made this five weekends in a row for my kids' lunches and it has turned out great every time. About to make it again!
No edits made and it came out delicious.
Excellent bread, I used 2/3 C honey, 3C Montana Praire Gold, 2 C whole wheat and finnished with AP flour until I had the right spring back. Will be making this recipe again, really tasty!!
Made it and my family loved it. I did add a little extra honey, and did 3 cups whole wheat instead of 2 cups. Turned out great

The only thing I add is: right after taking them out of the oven I take a cold stick of butter and rub it over the top of each. This step helps keep the top crust soft and adds a little richness to it.
My family love this bread, simply recipe but so good. I made it just like the recipe called for.
The bread is excellent. Much better than what you can buy

I really got irritated when I bought a loaf of bread from the supermarket and it didn't mold after three weeks in my cupboard. So I decided to tackle my fear of baking bread and give this one a try. I read all the reviews and increased the honey to 1/2 cup, increased the salt to 1.5 tsp and substituted salted butter for the oil. I used white whole wheat flour (2 cups), unbleached bread flour (2 cups) and all-purpose flour (3 cups). I used my Kitchen Aid and was able to incorporate all the flour. I kneaded the dough only a little, and that was probably a mistake, and based on other reviews, I didn't bake it the full 30 minutes, which was also a mistake as one of my loaves was a bit doughy. The other loaf, after a little longer in the oven however, was perfect and delicious! This will become our new normal. Thanks for posting!
My family raved about this!

This is a tasty and easy bread to make! I followed the recipe and it is truly delicious - rave reviews from friends and family, too. The thought of making bread used to intimidate me but it's not nearly as hard as I thought. Nothing I've bought in a store comes close to this I made at home! Several reviewers suggested more honey than the 1/3 cup but I found it plenty satisfying as written.
Did not make any changes, It was Great. Loved it.
I used 1/2 c. Of honey. Not too sure how much white flour I used. I added one cup at a time until the dough was elastic as I was kneading. Super yummy, will be making again
Stick to 25 mins, I had a larger bread mould, so I put the rest of the dough as little buns, worked out ok.

After reading the reviews before making it, I too doubled the amt of honey, and I also swapped one of the cups of white flour for the wheat. I'm a newbie to kneading so I literally was kneading for 45 minutes with pauses to google "how to tell when it's done kneading" and "how to knead dough" since it was taking forever. ;) But somehow, this turned out really well. It tastes great, and my kids loved it - my 5 yr old just keeps asking for more bread. The cooking time was spot on and I pulled it out right between 25 and 30 minutes. I'm looking forward to trying one of the suggestions of putting a handful of oats in it some time. I'll be making this again.

First bread I've ever made. It turned out great. I used 4 cups of white flour instead of 5 , a little bit less than a half a cup of honey and little less than 2 teaspoons of salt and I used my Kitchenaid to do the rest. My dough was rising in the oven with open oven door at 175 F for about hour and a half and then I let it rise in the loaf pans in the oven for another 40 minutes. Baked at 375 for 25 min. I love the taste (does not taste like flour), consistency and pretty much everything about this bread. The cool thing about it is that I was able to use organic flour and make it as healthy as it gets for my family. I had almost half a loaf by my self, I had to try a sandwich with lunch meat and pb&j, my dogs loved it with pb. Awesome recipe.

This is going to be my goto sandwich/toast/everyday bread recipe. I love it and can't wait to play with it a bit to see what cool variations it'll yield! Infinitely softer and more flavorful than any wheat bread recipe I've tried thus far.
Excellent Bread! I changed a few things: only added 3 cups all-purpose flour and added 3 cups whole wheat flour, and added a little extra honey.

My mother in law said that this was the best home made bread she has tasted and I have made several different types before too. Was very pleased with how it turned out. Will definitely use for years to come!
Surprisingly very easy to make and very good texture considering there is no bread flour in this recipe
A-Mazing!!! Fabulous bread recipe. Absolutely love it!
Fantastic! I used more honey as suggested and replaced a cup of white flour with wheat. So good!! I will bake again with maybe some oats on top.

I have baked this bread twice now and have been disappointed each time. Two years ago I baked this bread and it was awesome! Last week and again today I baked this bread and it was just ok. Edible, but lacking that wow factor that it seemed to have before. Maybe you guys can help me, what am I doing wrong? My bread never seems fluffy enough, and it usually cracks on the edge during baking. It doesn't taste much of honey, either.

Turns out very good - a family favorite! Only thing I did different was to add 2 Thse vital wheat gluten, which made the bread rise better and kept a nice texture to the loaf. I've made it twice now, same great results.
I love this bread so much.I make it all the time,even i give it away as gifts.It is so easy to make.I wish I could rate it higher.
This bread is delicious! I made half into a loaf and the other half into buns.
This is so easy and delicious

At one time I baked quite a bit of bread, but circumstances made it more trouble than it was worth for a few years. I recently rededicated myself to bread making and this is the first recipe I tried. My yeast was almost 5 years old, but I proofed it and it seemed workable. I made only a couple of small changes, using 3 cups of WW flour and about 4 cups of AP, and I used about one half cup of honey. I put it in a warm oven to rise and it took over two hours to double in bulk. Was it the old yeast or the extra WW flour, I don't know. The second rise was also slow, over an hour. I baked the loaves about 30 minutes and they turned out beautifully and oh, so tasty. BTW, my KA mixer handled the kneading with no problem, about 7 minutes on speed 2. For my first bread effort in years, I couldn't be happier. Next time, I will make some small changes to personalize the bread, but this is an excellent basic recipe.
I read all the reviews and decided to go with the recipe as written. It is very heavy and dense. I think I will try again and alter it with some of the reviewers suggestions next time.

I tried this bread twice today and the first was a utter failure. 7 cups of flour was waaay to much. The second try, I opted for 3 cups of wheat flour and 4 cups of all purpose flour. I also used 1/2c of honey. After letting it rise the first time and splitting the dough, I noticed that it took way more time to rise than the first rise. I only gave it 3 stars because it took almost 4 hours to complete. I haven't tasted it yet, but this was my very first attempt at a yeast yielding bread. I have been making banana and banana nut bread which is quite easy.

My husband and I decided to make this together. About the only thing we did correctly according to the recipe was the temp of the water. Seriously. I was reading the recipe and, like most men, he refused to listen to me. We halved everything except the honey which I wish we would have added even more. It was the first bread we've ever made and it was pretty darn good.

Great recipe! The only things I changed was I used white wheat flour and 2 tablespoons of yeast and I sprinkled oats on top before baking. The flavor is delicious. The loaf came out slightly heavy though. I prefer it a little bit lighter, but it could have been something I did or the slight changes I made since I'm a novice bread maker still. 
I gave 5 stars because my family loved it!

A very easy recipe but VERY bland. I usually love multi grain bread but decided to try this recipe since it was homemade bread and I will not be trying again. Soo plain even with 1/2 cup of honey instead of 1/3 cup.

There is way too much flour in this recipe. I couldn't even get all of it to mix with adding more water to the recipe. Also without letting the yeast sit for a few minutes it took almost 4 hours for it to rise. It baked nicely but even with using double the honey it tastes like flour.

So easy! Used my stand Kitchenaid mixer. Kneaded for 10 minutes. Let rise in a warm oven both times. I added 1/2 cup quick oats to dough, and used 1/2 cup of honey. When I placed them in pans for the second rise, I first brushed tops with milk and sprinkled on quick oats. Then let rise final time (took 45 mn for second rise) and baked at 375 for 23 minutes only. Took out of oven, brushed tops with melted butter. We had ours with homemade cinnamon, honey butter.

This is a fabulous recipe!! I've been trying to find a good sandwich bread for our family, and this is it! I followed the recipe exactly (it was very easy!) and I have two amazingly soft and yummy loaves!! Thanks so much!

I just took it out of the oven ten minutes ago and shared a slice with my granddaughter. Delicious. I took other people's suggestions and doubled the honey. I used the exact amount of flour it called for and thought it was not going to come out right as it was very difficult to knead and I read the comments of others, AFTER I had added all the flour, kneaded it and stuck it in the oven to proof. (my oven has a bread proof setting.) It took twice as much time to rise, both times. However, it was worth it, it is delicious. I will make this again.

This is a staple in our house. Thanks to some of the reviews I realized I had been putting too much white flour into it. Made some the correct way yesterday and it's even better. My family loves it! I only use about 4.5C of white flour, and I measure the weight of the flour out on a mail scale (4.5oz per cup). Otherwise I follow the recipe to the tee!
Awesome bread and easy to make! Second loaf I ever made in my life and it was amazing, will never buy bread again! Would like a Kitchen-Aide Mixer for Christmas! But its fun making it by hand too!

I asked my grandma what her wheat bread recipe was, since it tasted delicious. Her recipe was complicated, but it included honey instead of sugar, and wheat, so I thought this recipe would be a good fit. I followed the recipe exactly, and it was OK. The bread is shaped like a rectangle (completely fat on top) and it was pretty dense. It tastes OK, but doesn't have much flavor. I realize that wheat take time to rise, or sometimes doesn't rise at all, and maybe that was part of my problem. Also, I live in a high altitude, so that may may a difference. Overall....it was just....OK.
This has become our daily loaf! Very simple recipe that you can adjust to your liking but is perfect the way it is. Great recipe!

Are you kidding me!?! This is the best bread I have ever eaten. Honestly, it doesn't matter what kind of sandwich I make, it's a 1000 times better than before. I pretty much followed the recipe as written, with the exception of adding one packet of Maple and Brown Sugar Oatmeal, as one other review suggested. I used to buy rolls from a local bakery to use for sandwiches...not any more! To make sure my 1st loaves were done, I checked their internal temperature. When they reached 190 degrees I pulled them out of the oven. They were perfect. This is now my go-to recipe for daily bread and I can't wait to experiment with different flavors of oatmeal. Yummmmmy!!!
Easy, simple, and yummy!

I am a newbie with bread and followed the directions except for substituting a cup of white wheat flour for one of the all-purpose to give it more gluten content and had trouble getting the bread to rise. The loaves still came out very soft and tasty though. Next time I will add more water. The protein level in the flour is very high, which means it will absorb more liquid, so according to King Arthur flour, you should add two teaspoons extra liquid per cup of flour to the recipe you are using. So just a bit more water and a warmer place to rest and rise should do the trick!

I make this bread often for my family. We love it. It's so simple to make, is economical and the dough is so easy to work with, I do cut the recipe in half because there's no way we'd be able to eat 2 loaves of bread before they go bad. I use one packet of yeast and use a 1/2 cup of honey. The best part is that it calls for no eggs, milk or butter so it's truly economical for those looking for an affordable bread recipe. The bread comes out so soft and sweet. This is one of my favorite bread recipes on AR.
It was amazing! The little bit of honey was just enough to be great!!!

Success! I had no problems making this recipe, and I have a tough time getting even pizza dough to rise! Needless to say, I was going in with lower expectations. Dough doubled nicely, and I took the suggestion of the baker who used the microwave and a bowl of hot water as a proofing box of sorts. Baked for 30 minutes, and the result was a light, soft loaf with good crumb. I also doubled the honey, then added 3 TB of granulated sugar for good measure because I prefer a sweeter bread. Will make this again.

I cut the entire recipe, except honey, in half as I only wanted one loaf. I also only used all purpose flour, no wheat flour. I also put honey down the center of the loaf directly before baking it. I ran it down with a knife to bake into the top of the bread, giving it a dimple down the middle. I think the bread came out nice, but it took forever to rise. I put the oven on to 170 and let it cool down for a few minutes,then put the bread in there for an hour with a damp cloth over it to rise. I had to do that both times and it never did rise as much as desired. I only gave it three stars mostly because even half the recipe took about 4-5 hours to get a loaf of bread, not the two stated. We ended up going to the store to buy bread for dinner and this finish when we were ready to go to bed. If you make the entire recipe, I'd double the honey.

honestly maybe it was just me but this bread didnt turn out all that great. it crumbles easily and kept falling apart. i thought it was just me. this was my 3rd time making this particular recipe and it was the same every time. ive never had a problem with any other bread i made before so i guess it just wasnt meant to me.

I was so proud of myself when I made this. It was very easy to make and was so excited when it rose beautifully. Glad I doubled the honey. Next time, i would add a little more salt in it. One thing for sure, I won't be buying any more bread from now on :D Thank you for sharing!
Loved this recipe i added a little less flour and more wheat flour due to i love wheat so much and it turned out great. Thank you for sharing.

For all you newbie bread bakers: the proportions on this recipe are all wrong. You can't put in 7 freaking' cups of flour and 2 cups of water and have it turn out. It needs to be 3 1/2 cups of water. (Also, the picture at the top is of bread that was allowed to over-rise. My husband used to be a commercial baker -- he knows his stuff.)

I tried this recipe and it seemed as though 2 cups of water is not enough. I was not able to add the full amount of flour. Other than that, this is a good, simple recipe. I will definitely make it again but with more water to begin. This bread had a good flavor and is very simple.

Not the greatest. Mine barely moved on the 2nd rise (yeast proofed fine) and I kept giving it time to rise until I finally did the "imprint test" and it said it was ready despite looking pretty much the same height as when it went in. I knew it wouldn't rise much cooking. It came out with a good consistency, but it was small of course, and pretty bland, though I followed the suggestions of increasing the honey. I don't know what I was expecting with taste, maybe I'm an artisan bread snob? I was trying to find a simple wheat bread for my kids to substitute for store-bought. I guess this would be it, but the issues with rising - I've never had a bread not rise so I'm a bit perplexed. I'll give it another try it again before writing it off.
This recipe did not turn out as it should have. Very bland, not fluffy at all. Will use for French toast so as not to waste it. Very disappointed.

Tasted pretty good but it took A LOT longer than 45 min to rise...not to mention the additional time it took to rise in the loaf pans. Would have given a higher rating if the recipe was clear about how long the whole process takes.
Easy. Came out great. Although next time I will be adding more honey and maybe a bit more salt. It's got a great texture, heavy duty enough for sandwich bread without being a chore to chew.

This is yummy! I did make some changes by adding 1 t wheat gluten and adding 4 C wheat flour and 2 1/2 c white flour. We had this bread with our BLT's tonight. A tip I learned on you tube is to not knead the bread with more flour it makes it more crumbly. I lightly oiled the countertop and hands and had no issues of sticking. Thanks for sharing:)
